thread.title: 'Quiet, peaceful, wonderful' Oregon college reeling after mass shooting
thread.title_full: 'Quiet, peaceful, wonderful' Oregon college reeling after mass shooting | OregonLive.com

author: The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: 'Quiet, peaceful, wonderful' Oregon college reeling after mass shooting
text:
This week marked the start of the school year for students and staff at Umpqua Community College, where a mass shooting unfolded Thursday.
For some students, it was only their second day of classes at the small school outside of Roseburg.
"Everything is new," college board member Sharon Rice said by phone.
But now, the school year will pause while the community grieves.
Authorities said an unnamed 20-year-old man shot and killed several before he was confronted by police.
Ten died, including the shooter, and at least seven others were injured in the gunfire.
The bloodshed at the rural campus stunned the community.
"I've been glued to the television set," Rice said. "I'm just really shocked. This is a very quiet, peaceful, wonderful community to live in."
Classes had only just begun, but the school will remain closed until at least Monday.
In the meantime, the American Red Cross has sent and is recruiting mental health workers to respond to Roseburg, a spokeswoman for the organization said.
Wendy Weikum, a nine-year college board member, said the school community is very close.
"My heart goes out to all of those who experienced some loss and those who were injured also," she said.
Soon after the shooting, Weikum got a call from a student.
"She was very shaken up," Weikum said.
The student told Weikum she had been in the classroom next to where the shooting happened. She had called Weikum to let her know that she wouldn't be able to make her piano lesson tonight.
"I didn't ask any specifics," Weikum said. "She just said she heard it."
Vanessa Becker, another board member, said the board would try to figure out how to lend support for those affected.
"It's a tragedy â€“ I'm speechless," Becker said by phone. "It's just really sad, and we're really concerned about our students and our staff and our community."
Umpqua Community College, located about three hours south of Portland, has a student body of almost 5,000 students, most part time. The school sits six miles outside the timber town of Roseburg.
Like community colleges in Oregon, Umpqua offers a lower-cost higher education to any student who wishes to enroll. Its programs include automotive technology, aviation, winemaking, green technology and hospitality.
Mercy Medical Center in Roseburg received 10 patients from the shooting scene, the hospital said via Twitter.
"Please continue to pray," the hospital tweeted.
Elin Miller, who was a school board member until July, said it's been hard for her and others in the community to not know the names of the victims.
"It's going to be quite an impact when we realize who is affected and what families," she said.
But Miller said the community is resilient. A fund has already been created to help families, she said.
To donate: Visit any Umpqua Bank and mention the Greater Douglas United Way : UCC Relief Fund.
Betsy Hammond and Anna Griffin of The Oregonian contributed to this report.
-- Emily E. Smith and Rebecca Woolington
esmith@oregonian.com
